awd_titl_txt: CSR: Medium: Collaborative Research: Foundations of Cache Network Operations for Content Delivery
awd_abstract_narration:
When a user goes online to read the news, watch videos, buy products, play games, or use a social network, the content accessed by the user is delivered to his/her device by a large Internet-scale network called a content delivery network (or, CDN for short). A CDN may consist of hundreds of thousands of servers located in thousands of data centers around the world. Operating a large CDN  is challenging due to the sheer scale and diversity of the traffic and due to the vastness of their distributed server infrastructure. This research focuses on enabling highly efficient CDN operations.

The key goals of this project are minimizing the operating cost and maximizing the robustness of the network. This project develops techniques for mapping different traffic classes to servers, so as to optimize resource usage, increase hit rates, and lower bandwidth costs.  This project also develops adaptive and self-tuning systems that are robust to common sources of CDN variability, including object popularity/size, load, latency, and availability. Since CDNs are the key infrastructure enabling  web, video, and other online applications,  this project has a significant positive impact on the quality-of-experience of Internet users, while lowering the cost of Internet services.

The project will broaden participation by involving undergraduates in the research. Further, the project will help attract women to STEM through outreach activities, including "Tech Nights" and "Roadshows" for Middle-School girls, and including semi-annual "Career Advice talks"  to students from high school through grad school. The project will also incorporate topics in large-scale network operations in the curriculum. Finally, the project will invest significantly in outreach and tech transfer to the CDN industry by incorporating our research in production systems and enabling students to gain real-world experience in the CDN industry through internships.

All products of the project, including research papers, software, and data, will be made available to the public. In particular, the software and data produced by the project will be archived for at least five years, and even longer when feasible. There will be two software and data repositories: one at UMass Amherst (https://www.cs.umass.edu/~ramesh/Site/CODE_DATA.html) and the other at CMU (http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~harchol/SoftwareDataRepository.html).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on two key goals of Content Distribution Network (CDN) operations: minimizing the operating cost and maximizing the robustness and performance of the network. The project resulted in several research innovations.  Below we describe three of these.

One major direction of the project involved finding a way to speed up web requests which depend on queries to several different backend systems.  Such multi-backend requests are very common in large web services such as Facebook and Microsoft.  For such requests it is important that all of the backend systems respond quickly.  The solution developed in this project involves dynamic partitioning of cache space, to temporarily give more cache to backends that are slow, while reducing the cache space for backends that are fast.  The resulting system, called RobinHood, greatly improves the tail latency of requests as compared to the state-of-the-art solutions, when tested on Microsoft requests which involve more than 20 backend systems.

Another major direction of the project looked at ways to improve the performance of extremely large, terabyte capacity caches.  The solution was to utilize flash devices for caching, in combination with DRAM cache.   Unfortunately, using flash devices required overcoming several major obstacles, requiring the development of several new techniques to make flash devices more suitable for caching.   The resulting product is the CacheLib system which is deployed at Facebook and serves over 70 services at Facebook.  CacheLib is a general-purpose caching engine that facilitates the easy development and maintenance of new caches.  Particularly exciting is the fact that, through this project, CacheLib was able to secure the proper approvals at Facebook to allow it to be made public in August 2021.

A third focus of the project was finding a way to cache very tiny objects on flash devices, given that flash devices are designed to be much better suited for caching large objects.   This is important because many social media services have very large working sets consisting of billions of tiny objects.   The solution was a new flash cache design called Kangaroo, which combines a large cache together with a very small cache.    Experiments using traces from Facebook and Twitter show that Kangaroo improves upon the state-of-the-art caches with respect to flash write rates and hit ratios.   Kangaroo won the Best Paper Award at SOSP 2021. 

The project also produced several broader impacts.  Three graduate students received their PhD degrees under the direction of co-PI Harchol-Balter.  All three were immediately hired into tenure-track faculty positions as assistant professors.  One is at Cornell in their ORIE department; one is at UNC-chapel Hill in their Computer Science department; one is about to go to Northwestern in their IEMS department.  Additionally five undergraduates were supervised by co-PI Harchol-Balter during this grant.  Five Best Paper or Best Student Paper awards were received during this grant, including the prestigious 2022 George Nicholson Prize in Operations Research.  The grant also resulted in the writing of a new undergraduate textbook.  The book is titled “Introduction to Probability for Computing,” and is being published by Cambridge University Press.  It will be out in October 2023.  It will also be available for free online, along with free teaching resources.  A new class was developed and run during this grant, called “Performance Tools.”  The class teaches graduate students how to frame their system research using queueing theory and then how to use queueing theory to improve the performance of their systems.  What is unique about the class is that it is taught using almost no math.  Additionally, the grant resulted in a new DEI course for graduate students and a major initiative at Carnegie Mellon University on improving the environment for female students in the Computer Science department.
